evidence: use an unstable isotope as a tracer molecule
measurements reflect the distribution of the tracer
signal corresponds to metabolism and physiological function
Once the tracer enters the body, it participates in normal metabolic processes.
The tracer molecule, an unstable isotope or radionuclide, is administered intravenously or orally.
The tracer molecule participates in normal metabolic processes.
As the tracer molecule emits gamma rays, these are detected.
The measurements of the gamma rays reflect the distribution of the tracer molecule.
The signal from nuclear imaging corresponds to metabolism and physiological function.

concepts.term: nuclear imaging allows us to see how tissues are working

evidence: This tracer can be administered in different ways - most commonly through intravenous injection, but in some cases, it can also be taken orally, for example, by drinking a small amount of radioactive liquid.
The physical principles of nuclear imaging can be summarized as follows.
Once the tracer enters the body, it participates in normal metabolic processes.
In other words, nuclear imaging allows us to see how tissues are working, not just how they look.

triples.evidence: This tracer can be administered in different ways - most commonly through intravenous injection, but in some cases, it can also be taken orally, for example, by drinking a small amount of radioactive liquid.
